reviewText:
First of all, I played the game before its release on steam thus explaining my playtime. Also, I voluntarily will not speak of the game's details because it's not what I want to defend in this review.
Café 0 ~The Drowned Mermaid~ perhaps isn't the best visual novel ever made nor the prettiest.
It's probably one of the ugliest but, as a wise and just as ugly man once said, what matters is what's inside! And what's inside is okay! It offers an average and, somehow, a bit compelling story focused on characters interesting enough for you to keep on playing the game.
I went through several states that I'd like to develop from before playing to reaching the true ending:

1) The discovery: I was truly amused, mostly by the graphics (just like you I assume) and yet was curious about this setting (like you once again, explaining why you are currently reading this review).

2) The purchase:  I ended up purchasing it due to my curiosity taking over my reasoning I guess (not that I regret it today), and felt this feeling ,which was a mixture of both amusement and a bit of nervousness, just like before you go on exploring the complete unknown of a safe experience.

3) The playthrough: I played for a straight 4 hours (as I remember), at night alone in my house and went through a rollercoaster of feelings mainly composed of inquisitiveness and mockery at times which truly fulfilled those 4 hours I spent on the game. I was also really satisfied by the endings delivering something that can rarely be found in gaming experiences in my opinion.

4) The post-experience: I went from making fun of the game, upon discovering the game, to making fun of the game and defending its qualities, because it deserves it. I even lost some credibility in some friends' mind but it doesn't matter because not only did I have a good time but I also became wiser as of judging one's book by its cover and therefore, by extension, learning to give a chance to everything and everyone.

Some might point out the price of the game, perhaps a bit expensive for its content, and I can only agree but once it goes on sale, I truly hope that this review would have convinced you to give this game a chance. A chance it really deserves. Thank you.
voteText: 17 of 20 people (85%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This was a decent game. I found the story to be fairly well written even though the character interactions themselves werent very well written at all. Strange dichotmy there, ay? Not sure what to say about that except that it exists. Good story, poor dialogue. The graphics themselves arent anything to write home about, at all. In fact, I would say they work against this game, as it's a graphic novel, and an important aspect of keeping you interested with a interactive novel is the graphics, or at least the artwork such as it is. That aspect of the game wasnt exactly a failure, but it really wasnt inspiring at all, and made the reading a bit more tedious than it should have been.

That said, this game is also super fast to play through, and after the first playthrough, you can skip through most of the dialogue in replays so as to see the various endings without having o read the exact same dialogue over and over and over (there are 7 endings by my count, btw).

The topic itself is all about how to cope with your own mortality, in a sense. The protagonist having amnesia adds a nice twist to the tale.

All told, I think this game shows a lot of promise from the developer(s), but it in and of itself just barely gets a thumbs up, and I would buy this game on sale or via a bundle (the latter is how I got it actually).

5.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Cafe 0 ~ The Drowned Mermaid,

Is not a Visual Novel for just anybody. The subject that's being brought up in this VN is a bit different. It's about dying and finding peace in the fact itself.

The story itself is quiet interesting from time to time, but if falls short on depth in my opinion. The conversations with the important" characters are too shallow compared to other VN's of the same price. So
date: I would have expected more on that part.\nThe graphics are a bit different also. I can't say they're good
voteText: without trying to spoil anything
helpfulPercent: it's basically a good ending / bad ending thing. You make some choices and get some progression "stat" throughout the game so you're able to see how you're doing. That's the part I liked a lot
votesHelpful: because it's done in a different way than just displaying some numbers or bars.\n\nThe one thing I didn't like at all is that at the beginning you've got to enter a name. But
votesTotal: you're not told that you're supposed to enter a female name. So
votesFunny:
if you enter a male name it feels like you're some kind of shemale. A bit weird..

Another negative thing about this VN is the fact that it falls short on length. It doesn't take that long to complete a path and the fact that there're several endings doesn't make it any better. It feels like a cheap way by the developer to stretch the game time.

So to put it all in a list:

Pros:
-Interesting/different subject.
-Interesting story.
-Nice music.

Cons:
-Too short.
-Repeating dialogs.
-Lack of information when entering a name.
-The different endings feel forced.
-Towards the end of the story it feels like a rushed product.

As you can see there're more negative things than positive aspects about Cafe 0. The thing is that I don't regret buying this Visual Novel

reviewText:
Stats at the Time of Reviewing
Hours on Record: 5,1
Achievement Progress: 21/21 (100 %)
Summary
In CAFE 0 ~The Drowned Mermaid~, you play as a girl, whom you can name, though if you have the voiced version, the other characters will refer to you by the original name “Marin Umino”. The main character is unfortunately, or fortunately, depending on how you look at it, not voiced. CAFE 0 is listed as mystery/horror, though I would personally not call it a horror VN, as it lacks the tension and fear, being staples of the genre; the mystery is definitely there, though. The gist of the plot is that the main character has died and ends up at a mysterious café. Here, she is given the chance to relive the 7 last days of her life to prepare for what lies ahead. She has no memories left and is unsure of what to do with her “second life”. It is up to you to decide how she spends this time. There are 3 prominent characters, each representing 1 path, one being the true path, requiring items obtained at the end of the other 4. Then there is also a “bad” ending if you choose not to follow a path. There are 6 endings in total, and I would recommend going for all of them, as understanding the full story and changing your opinions on things and characters with each path is a pleasant experience. If you like the idea of going through it all, CAFE 0 is a solid purchase with a satisfying conclusion and good development.

The Bad
The only bad thing that really comes to mind is that the voice-overs are DLC. They do add to the experience, in my opinion, and it would be easier to recommend the game if they were in the full game without the extra price tag.

The “So-so”
The editing could be better. It is not terrible, and does not take away from the experience, but the English used in places could have used some more work, as it sounds unnatural and sometimes weird. I have seen mixed opions on the art, but I, personally, think it looks good enough and, as I am focused on the plot, I have no reason to point it out as a definite negative.

The Good
The plot, essentially. The concept of CAFE 0 is intriguing to me, and the game delivers the story in a good way. Each of the 4 paths, leading to the true path, gives you a different point of view and different ideas of how the characters are and how they are related to the main character before she died. Until the true path, I had mixed opinions and views on each of the 3 most prominent characters, which made each path interesting to play through, as I wanted to see how they would change with each one. The true ending then provides the last pieces and puts the puzzle together, leaving you with a satisfying conclusion to an interesting mystery plot. It kept me hooked, which is what a good book, or in this case, a good VN, is supposed to do. I also felt that I could relate to the main character on the “evil” paths, but that might be saying more about me than the game.

The Verdict
Overall, CAFE 0 ~The Drowned Mermaid~ is a solid, intriguing mystery VN worth purchasing. The only thing I would consider is the price. As this is a very short VN, the full price is a bit high, but on a sale, I definitely recommend getting it if you are looking for a good mystery VN.

reviewText:
I like VNs generally, but cannot recommend spending any of your money or time on this one. It feels like a half-hearted effort.

Everything is pretty bad, honestly: the art is distractingly bad, the story is boringly bad and poorly written, even the controls are bad. How one is able to screw up controls in a such a simple and short VN? Require the keyboard once and once only. Or if you use keyboard to advance, require mouse and only mouse on choices. It might be the engine though and I wouldn't be griping on it if the game had any redeeming qualities.

Good thing? It's short. 4 replays and you're done.

reviewText: I often find games that give me conflicting emotions are far easier to reccomend, and this is such a case. For the majority of my playtime, I absolutely loathed this game; the characters, the dialogue--all amounted to some of the most infuriatingly childish attempts at romance and edginess in a game with some very straightforward choices that lead to almost the exact same thing. I almost gave up, writing it off as another game more catering to tweens and their fledging libidos, and I am so glad I didn't.\n\nYou see, this is an otome visual novel; basically, this is meant for girls, and in just about every way, The Drowned Mermaid is that. At a lot of points especially I was put off by the main character and the choices offered, and all of the endings at first seemed extremely shallow, going the I love you forever~~" route or the "burn for all eternity" route (which were always far more interesting). However
recommended: this shallow presentation to some extremely shallow characters is actually a partial ruse for something much more intricate and sinister. While this does not discount the dialogue as being amateurish
hoursPlayed: somehow it adds to the intrigue this game builds up. With each ending
voteText: you get closer to the true one
helpfulPercent: and believe me when I say it won't take you long.\nBy the end of my little journey

reviewText:
Pros:
-Interesting plot with multiple routes and endings.
-The soundtrack is nice.
-The art is good.
-The dev seems to care about the game and helps when s/he can.

Cons:
-It's short so I'm not sure I can say it's really worth its full price.

At first I found it hard to get into this game, mostly because of the female protagonist. But in the end I liked it a lot and truly enjoyed every second of it, mostly because of the true ending which was turned out really unexpected and took me by surprise.

Do I recommend it?

Of course. But whether to buy it at full price or wait for a discount is up to you. Not because of the title's quality, but for its content, since it's pretty short.

reviewText:
[Neutral Review]

CAFE 0 ~The Drowned Mermaid~ is an average Visual Novel that tells us the story of Marin, a girl who died a miserable death, going seven days back into the past with the help of a mysterious waiter from a weird cafe. She tries to uncover the reasons behind her death, since she has no memories of who is she or what happened.

The player must complete four endings in order to be able to get the true ending, that explains what really happened with Marin. The Novel mechanic is kind of strange. I don't want to spoil your playthrough, so I will not give anymore detail. The graphics are really above average, the BGM is repetitive and the plot in general is a bit poor.

Even though the game is really short and a bit repetitive (I took like 3 hours to get all endings and achievements), it's true ending can be a little unexpected and make us think twice before trust into someone else. As we see in the game, people can be selfish and blinded by their own desires, being true monsters sometimes.

As for me, this is a game for fans of the genre, or for those who are looking for some kind of existential thought. I don't think that this Visual Novel should be so expensive ... so I recommend to buy it with a good discount.

reviewText:
Before continuing with this review, I should mention that this is the first and only visual novel I have played. I got it free from a giveaway, so I didn't have to pay money for this or the Japenese voice acting DLC. I honestly only bothered playing it to unlock the steam trading cards.

It should take about 2-3 hours to unlock every achievement in the game. Sadly, this did not give me enough time to earn every trading card, so I left the game running while doing other tasks to get the rest of the trading cards.

It goes without saying that the artstyle is horrible, so I won't talk about that in depth. Just look at the screenshots/trailer on the game's store page.

-Spoilers-

The story focuses on the death of Marin Umino (you can change her name), who finds herself in a mysterious Cafe without her memories. A waiter at the cafe hands her a glass of water, and after she drinks it, she somehow finds herself with her school swim team recovering from almost drowning. When she returns home, she finds the waiter from the cafe, Sui, in her home and he tells her that she only has 7 days to live, and that she must prepare her heart for the afterlife.

The story has a total of six endings: two good endings, two evil endings, a bad ending, and a true ending.

You get the good and evil endings by talking exclusively to Shou and Tooru (getting a good ending if you say nice things, and an evil ending if you say mean things. Both characters have a good and evil ending associated with them). After each ending, your character recieves an item that she holds onto in the every playthrough onwards. You get the true ending by showing the four items your character recieves after each ending to Ami in one playthrough. You get the bad ending by doing anything other than the five paths I just mentioned.

After you unlock each ending, an option appears in the extras menu called Welcome to Cafe 0." Complete a dialog with Sui to unlock every achievement."

reviewText:
Cafe 0 is the second game that came out by the developer roseVeRte and it's a visual novel that has elements of the supernatural and horror.  You take on the role of Marin Umino who has just died and finds herself in an unusual-looking cafe.  A waiter named Sui approaches her and offers her the chance to relive the last 7 days of her life.

So that's basically, the premise of the story.  It's pretty short if you plan on playing through the game only once but since I like replaying games to learn the entire story, I found myself interested in understanding what happened to Marin that led to her death.  To understand the true story, it's necessary to play through most of the good and bad paths to get the necessary items needed for it.  Although I'm not usually a fan of anything that has a horror theme for personal reasons, I do like this developer's games so I wanted to give Cafe 0 a chance.  Overall, I liked it and the story drew me in.  ^^

The art is similar to the developer's first game dUpLicity~Beyond the Lies~ so there may be mixed reviews on that aspect.  The music was decent and it fit in well with certain events that happened in the story and all.  Overall, I would say that if you like this developer's games, then you'll most likely like Cafe 0.  However, I do think that the East Tower series is better, as I played that series before I touched Cafe 0.  (I have yet to play How to Take Off Your Mask as I'm posting this review so I can't comment on it yet.)

reviewText: I can only recommend this title for those who haven't played visual novels before. Cafe 0 is just barely tolerable for casuals and veterans alike, but at the same time it is a competent gateway into the genre, for what that is worth. It's a good idea to get it only when it's for sale on a very cheap-as-chips bundle, which conspicuously happens quite often. It would also be wise to follow this guide if you wish to complete Cafe 0 in three hours or less.\n\nAs a last note, I do not have the Japanese voice acting DLC for Cafe 0, and given how the dialogue and story isn't necessarily great, I'll go out in a limb and say it's nonessential.

reviewText:
At first, I wasn’t going to recommend this game. But then I decided to get all the achievements and see if anything would change through the story.

And boy, things got f*cking WILD.

I wasn’t expecting AT ALL the true ending. Or the other bad endings. I thought it was going to be a cliché romantic VN, but I was wrong… and I’m glad because of it. Yes, the character art isn’t the best, especially the lack of facial expressions… But to be really honest, I think that the originality of the story shines through all of this. It’s a short VN, there are a few “ok what’s going on” moments… But it was a really interesting concept. I love mystery/horror visual novels, so this one just made my day. The Japanese voice acting was okay, nothing special. I guess that the only VA I liked the most was Sui’s. And speaking of him, I think it would be awesome to see this character again, in another story. The whole Cafe 0 concept is quite nice, even if there’s a few plot holes.

7/10. I recommend getting this game on sale, since it’s quite short. I wish I could give more points but unfortunately the inexistent emotions of the characters almost ruined the experience for me on my first playthrough. You have to be persistent, and stay alert for the details.

reviewText:
This visuell novel has a cruel story and it start with a puzzle. You need to end first 4 endings to get the puzzle pieces to get the real end and to light the truth. You see 2 good endings and 3 bad endings all a part of hope or of trueness, but which one is one? So you need to play 5 story-lines, most time its only feels like much filling but that is normal in every game, movie or book but some parts like the mirror scene are boring and get on the 2nd walk skiped with fast forward option because no big changes most time. But the end was really not bad, not really surprising because some details in the walks before like a smile or other stuff but i find its one of the better visual novel stories i played (even if i not play very much).

Graphics are not good and not bad. Most people could do it better or this standard so i give 7 of 10 points to it. Sure it could be better but its not so important. Sound is okay not nerving and not be making the game much better 6,5 points here and the story gets on the way trough the game 7 points (ignore the boring mirror parts and mornings, rest is a bit to short) but the end get 9,5 of 10 points for me, maybe i overdo it, but without the little signs before it would be really astonish but not so believable so it was a hard way for the developer to make it not to much and not to less and i find it hit it very well and a good ending is for me the most important point of a game like Zelda Majoras Mask or Metroid Prime 1-3 get the best/ full ending.

So for visual novel genre fans this game should be good, for others only if they want a story like a comic/ manga but dont need action or something and only if you hold till the end of all walks for the rest of the gamers this game should be the right choice, the storyline is not everyones (only SPOILER: If you love betray tales it could be something you like). I give this game for this well tought narrative 82%, but if you dont like VS, let your hands of it, if you dont know it, watch trailer and play maybe first some free VN. I would prefer a discount of 50 better 66-75 % or more to pay not to much, but here work FEW developers hopefully with a low bugdet many hours, dont forget how much work and hard a game development is. Thank you for reading and enjoy your time.

reviewText:
Intriguing concept with not that intriguing execution. We play as a girl, that find herself in weird, under water place, called Cafe 0. We meet equally weird blue-haired waiter, drink glass of water and then... We're back in reality and it turns out that we've almost drowned in pool, during swimming competition. The thing is... We don't have any memories. We don't know who we are and who are people around us. We can't even see our reflection in the mirror. If that wasn't bad enough, blue-haired waiter shows up again and inform us, that we will die after seven days and that we have to prepare ourselves to our journey into the afterlife.

Since then our task is to speak with of the three other main characters - our, supposedly, best friend Amy, our ex boyfriend and school doctor, who is weirdly close to us. Endings depends on who will we choose as our company and what kind of answers we will give them. I think there's a six endings total. Of course all of those characters are clearly hiding something.

Good thing about this game is that it does not give us schematic characters and non of the classic love story. It's a little deeper and a little darker (though not deep and dark enough, when you consider it's potential). Bad thing? It's short. Really short. And not realistic the slightest. Hey, I get it, it's a game, but if someone finds out that they have only seven days before they die, they won't just limit themselves to one short talk with only one important person during a day. And protagonist doesn't have her memories. She should be focused on getting as much information as possible. Protagonist's reactions to certain situations also aren't very realistic - though, sadly, it's a plague of visual novels, that take many serious or shocking revelations with merely a shrug. Protagonist of this game, for example, does not protest the slightest about the fact that she is supposed to day in the seven days. In theory, it's kind of explained by her feeling" that it may happened
date: but it actually make it all less believable
hoursPlayed: that all of the endings are linked to each other in some way - you need to go through them all to have the full picture before you. After each ending you get a special item
voteText: that you get to keep during your next play - it almost creates an illusion that we're in the never ending cycle and that was definitely a good part.\n\nThe biggest flaw of this game is the fact that it doesn't truly exploit this intriguing premise. Instead of giving us something really deep

reviewText:
It was a short but pleasant game. Sometimes the plot seemed too shallow (like instantly falling for guy who's /totally/ acting suspiciously while you know him for about a day) but after beating the whole game i must say i quite enjoyed it. I didn't expect some plot points and they were actually nicely put together. I really liked the heroine, who was pretty assertive... especially in the true ending. Ahaha.
The only thing that i'm not positive about is how rushed the plot felt, but i guess there's no helping that since the game takes place in such a short time.
I liked voice acting and art. Many people complain about art in roseverte games, but i honestly don't mind? It's not beautiful, but i stopped caring about that after a while, since i got more interested in plot than what i see.
Personally, i recommend this game. It was satisfying and enjoyable. Not a masterpiece, but very good.

this game is bad for my heart, but it's actually good. If you getting sick of Lovely dovey kind of otome game, this is a good one. It's like a brick of reality just hit you in the face.

They should have done like Amnesia, subtitude the name with something else so it does sound like it intereact with you. But even whithout it, i think you will still enjoy it, since some people dont understand then and just skip before even the character finish talking.

And when clicking of choice, they give the sign of what kind of ending we going to end up with is good. The white butterfly is good, while the black butterfly is bad ending. At least I know that which choice is the right one. This is good for the beginners.

The plot is nice. It's a short honestly. To feel it worth buying is when you get all of the ending, like until you get the true ending. It make sense and can feel how scary is reality. It's sad, but the waiter is there to help you ;)

Honestly I like this game, but maybe it's because it's me who played it, I don't know about the others.

reviewText:
Ushio Marin wakes up in front of a café, in the middle of nowhere, without any of her memories. This café, however, is not your regular run-of-the-mill café: it lets you re-experience the last 7 days of your life.

As one comes to understand pretty quickly, our MC is a young woman who just died, and whose last 7 days will be our case of study. How did she die? Why did she die so young?

What you see now is the past --- the last seven days before one's death.
Right from the get go, this visual novel does a good job of setting up the mystery scene and making ourselves ask the right questions.

...Maybe it did too well of a job compared to the rest of the VN, though. The prologue set my expectations a bit high, so the development, which can arguably be described as a pretty cheap dating sim, disappointed me greatly.

The true ending is decent enough. Without saying too much, it's a grim ending demonstrating where naive trust can lead, how relationships can affect your entourage and the twisted motivations of some people. It does suffer from the short length of the VN though (less than 3 hours), which greatly cuts and rushes character development and cheapens the true ending a bit by making its execution a little bit cliché.

Overall, a good setting that could have offered much more if the execution was more fleshed out. The art could be better, but it does its job well enough to be experienceable in my opinion. 6/10, would half-heartedly recommend on sale or in a cheap bundle.

reviewText:
Pros:
Melancholy, disturbing story that will linger with me.
Strong characterisation
I love the trope of replaying and getting more threads until you reach the true ending, and all facets of the truth.

Cons:
I don't like the art style much (but that can be due to personal preference)
Voice acting as an optional paid extra
Some grammatical errors

Neutral:
2-3 hours for a game that takes 2-3 hours to play through, and is the price of a movie ticket, depending on audio option

Overall, I think it is a beautiful VN that I am glad to have played.

reviewText:
CAFE 0 ~The Drowned Mermaid~, while a story of tragedy and more grim than usual otome games that focus on romance and whatnot, is one of the rare games that really left a lasting impression on me because of its unusually pessimistic approach in the psychological makeup of its characters. I actually played the voiceless version ages ago, and recently got the deluxe voiced version as a part of an amazingly cheap bundle (which is still ongoing on indiegala.com if you guys are interested, 3.99 for ALL 7 games by this developer!!!).

First lets discuss the game mechanics without giving away any spoilers. You are Marin Yumino (default name, can be changed but I keep it because people pronounce her name if I do), who has been given the chance to redo the last 7 days of her life to get closure on her death.
There is the added challenge of the heroine not remembering anything about her life, and there are 3 main characters you can interact with while trying to figure out the details of the life you had led until now.
The 2 men are potential romantic interests"
date: and each of them have 2 possible endings-one where you pick all the goodie-to-shoes choices and use this limited time to fall in love
recommended: and the other where you pick all the interrogating/suspicious choices and try to figure out if they had anything to do with your death. Like this you play 4 times (sounds tedious
hoursPlayed: but each route is pretty short so it doesn't take even half an hour to finish one)
voteText: every end will give you a plot item
helpfulPercent: and then you play the game for the 5th time you take those items to the 3rd character
votesTotal: and manage to figure everything out and get the "true end".\nTo be honest I can't review the story itself without giving too much away since the storyline is mysterious and interesting but short. I felt like the main concept of this game is how people can become twisted when they let their desires control them. There was a few things about the characters' motivations that confused me
votesFunny: but in general everything started to make sense once I started playing the true route and although the end was not 'happy'
commentsCount: my character got to do what I wanted to and that's what is important to me.\n\nSo should you play it? Depends on what you are looking for. If you are looking for a visual novel with a short but intriguing story that involves psychological analysis of the dark side of human nature
column16: then HELL YEAH get it on sale right now! But if you either don't like visual novels in general or want a happy and fluffy romance
column17:
this is not the game for you.

The one thing I want to say to the developer- THE LAST MINUTE OF THE TRUE END WAS EPIC  10/10 CAN'T WAIT FOR MORE CAFE 0!

P.S. I want to punch Sui /^/^
"

reviewText:
This is quite possibly the most depressing VN I've ever played. The true (or should that be truth) ending is brutal. There is no happy ending. There is no off into the sunset with your true love. No way to undo the end, which given the entire nature of the game, you'd have thought there would be. But no...it's you, repeating the 7 days until you work out the truth. Which is grim.

If you like VN, go ahead. If you want a happy ending, avoid.

Also some of the scariest CG screens I've ever seen.

reviewText:
I've never really played a visual novel before, so it was a new experience for me. I got this game as part of a bundle, and such I don't think it's worth paying extra for the Japanese voice. The game could have worked even without it, honestly.

The story is divided into six endings, of which for most of them you have to fill in the pieces of the puzzle accordingly to get the two main good endings or the two main bad endings. Where the good endings are bittersweet and sentimental, the bad endings are full of hate - and I prefer the bad endings for that. It places thought onto what went on behind the scenes of the story.

Everything comes to a head in the True Ending (I won't spoil it, but it's by far the best ending).

The artwork isn't the best at some times, but there are some areas which I enjoyed the artwork (especially for the True Ending).

I've had an issue with achievements, where I cannot gain them, and the same 72 files on Steam fail to validate. However, it doesn't put me off from enjoying the game.

If you find it cheap or in a bundle, buy it. It kills a couple of hours.

reviewText:
Not a clear 'Not Recommend', more of a 'Meh'
This game is... weird. It's a mystery visual novel with some horror touches. I can't really write more about it without spoilers, so...

Spoilers Ahead
Ok, so I leant towards Not Recommend because overall this game is depressing as ♥♥♥♥. Aside of the helpless heroine every single character is an abusive a$$hole, who coerce, injure and eventually try to kill her. There's also teacher-student sexual abuse and blackmail. Lovely. Even the god-character, Sui, is an a$$hole, though at least he's a bit less damaging than the rest of the cast.

You can follow various decision routes: on the 'Good' one you end up as a very trusting person full of love towards others, on the 'Evil' one you end up as a distrustful and cold person, suspecting the people around you used and killed you. Then you can unlock the 'True' route, and guess what? Your suspicious version was right all along...

Overall I'm not sure of what to take away from this game. I mean, I guess it's possible that the creators just wanted to tell a story without further meaning, but I miss some kind of message or conclusion from it. The message would be what? Your best friend hates you and is plotting to kill you, the guy you grew up with as siblings is secretly lusting over you and pulls you into a relationship with wide age and power difference, only so when he gets bored of you he can pass you over to the popularity-chasing a$$hole who blackmailed him...? As I said, quite depressing.

Technical quality-wise the graphics are okay..ish, seen much better to be honest, and some of the CG screens have weird anatomy.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=564658789
The sound design is okay, the voiceover is a nice addition, it sounds professional.
The UI could be a bit better designed - that sizeable block of menu options permanently placed on the screen is kinda pointless and unnecessary. Those options could have gone in the top menu with the others.
The text sometimes has weird phrasings, it feels like the writers are not fluid in English.

Honestly the most enjoyable part of the game is the Extra, after all the endings are unlocked. Sui does some fourth wall breaking. But even then there are some dialogue options to ask about the more confusing aspects of the plot (albeit we don't get answers) -  I guess the developers felt it too that there were some gaps in the plot.

I'll finish the review with... this...
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=564659518

Also, at the time of this review, the price was $5.99 (40% off of $9.99) so it was a little procey as well.

reviewText: So I manily purchased this game because it was on sale and I wanted to play other Visual Novels other than the mainsteam CLANNAD and Fate. Well my first impression was wow, I'm not a guy, and then huh the story is straightoforward (or so it seemed). The first story was finished quite fast. You get 7 days and there is only about one or two choices that you can make per day, and that can be bad if you are used to many choices like in other games, but its not bad for this approach, it is just different. After I completed my one good ending, I decided to try the other paths, and yes, you can have bad endings. I decided a different approach because at this point I was not yet invested into the characters as in other games, and I must say that I was not disappointed. You can go chaotic evil and be rewarded by the game. Now the bad, the game can get repetitive very quickly and you will find yourself skipping through some dialogues as you will have heard them before. The fisrt menu is no apparent that you are supposed to make a choice and on my first playthrough I ended up making a selection when I did not mean to. Overall though, I had a decent experience with the game and I do recoment that you play it. For the record I played the Deluxe (Voiced Version) and the sound sounds well. I hope this project continues to grow.
